docs.lead_paragraph: Teenagers whose bodies clear nicotine unusually slowly from their systems became addicted to cigarettes at more than twice the rate of their peers, a study has concluded. In recent years, researchers have come to believe that genetic factors make some people more susceptible to addiction to tobacco, alcohol and other drugs, along with well-established social and environmental factors, said the study's lead researcher, Dr. Jennifer Lee O'Loughlin of McGill University in Montreal.
docs.abstract: Dr Jennifer Lee O'Loughlin, McGill University researcher, leads study on impact of nicotine retention on smoking addiction; study, published in journal Tobacco Control, finds that teenagers who process nicotine more slowly are more likely to become addicted to smoking, but smoked fewer cigarettes overall than other addicted teens; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Teenagers whose bodies clear nicotine unusually slowly from their systems became addicted to cigarettes at more than twice the rate of their peers, a study has concluded.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the picture a new study paints of how different levels of alcohol affect a driver's brain: The first drink makes it harder to stay in your lane, while the second makes it easier to ignore the fact that you're headed for the ditch. The study was published in the current issue of the journal Neuropsychopharmacology.

headline.main: This Is Your Brain on Beer

docs.abstract: Drs Vince D Calhoune and Godfrey D Pearlson of Yale University conduct study on effects of alcohol on driving ability; study, published in journal Neuropsychopharmacology, finds that second drink diminishes individual's judgement; holds that single alcoholic drink actually heightens driver awareness and makes driver more cautious; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study paints a specific picture of how different levels of alcohol affect a driver's brain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine a 20-year-old woman who refuses to eat anything except carrots and toast because she is afraid of gaining weight, even though she is 5-foot-8 and weighs only 99 pounds. She exercises to the point of exhaustion five mornings a week because, though she is bone-thin, she thinks her thighs are too flabby. Her periods are irregular, but she has never gone more than three months without menstruating. Another woman, who is also 20 and also 5-foot-8, has an opposite eating pattern. She goes without eating all day, and starting at 6 p.m. she eats nonstop, whatever she can get her hands on. Her favorite pastime is to sit in front of the television with a gallon of mocha-chip ice cream. She maintains a normal weight of 130 by occasionally forcing herself to vomit. But purging is not always easy in her college dormitory, with four young women sharing a single bathroom, so she ends up vomiting, on average, about once a week.

headline.main: Sorry. Your Eating Disorder Doesn't Meet Our Criteria.

docs.abstract: American Psychiatric Assn, which is currently revising its Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, is exploring ways to define eating disorders that do not strictly fall into two main categories of anorexia nervosa and bulimia; other disorders are now lumped into catch-all category known as Ednos, eating disorder not otherwise specified; various non-specific eating disorders described; Dr Michael First, Columbia University clinical psychology associate professor and member of assn planning group for manual, explains three criteria to be met before disorder is specifically named; often disorders without labels are not covered by health insurance and are not adequately researched; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For years, doctors have been relying on a vague nondiagnosis known by the acronym Ednos: eating disorder not otherwise specified.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM: Pregnant women should avoid cats. THE FACTS -- Most pregnant women know they should steer clear of alcohol and cigarettes. But cats? In fact, expectant mothers are often told that their cats are a potential threat. And while this may have the ring of an old wives' tale, experts say the warning should be taken seriously. Cats can carry Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that causes birth defects, miscarriages and death in people with weakened immune systems. The animals usually contract the disease by eating contaminated raw meat and small prey.
docs.abstract: Cats can be carriers of disease that cause illness in pregnant women, but adequate precautions reduce risk; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: While this belief may have the ring of an old wives' tale, experts say the warning should be taken seriously.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some stressful events seem to turn a person's hair gray overnight. Now a team of researchers has found that severe emotional distress -- like that caused by divorce, the loss of a job, or caring for an ill child or parent -- may speed up the aging of the body's cells at the genetic level.

headline.main: Stress and Distress May Give Your Genes Gray Hair

docs.abstract: Dr Elissa Epel and Dr Elizabeth Blackburn of University of California at San Francisco lead research into impact of stress on human cells; research, published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, suggests that extreme stress can cause process of cell reproduction to have shorter life span, which causes individual to age more quickly; stress has already been associated with lowered immune function; other factors such as how individual handles stress and genetic background also determine how stress affects human body; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A team of researchers has found that severe emotional distress may speed up the aging of the body's cells at the genetic level.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT SAN FRANCISCO

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

docs.lead_paragraph: "What would you do if it were your mother?" Patients ask me this simple question all the time. In fact, I have asked the very same question of doctors caring for my family. What better recommendation can there be? It's the medical equivalent of insider trading information.

headline.main: Why Good Friends Don't Always Make Good Doctors

docs.abstract: Doctors are often asked by patients and their families to suggest treatment they would recommend for their own family; Dr Kent Sepkowitz, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center infection control director, holds that doctors are not as effective when they are emotionally involved with patient (M)
docs.snippet: When painful medicine is involved, closeness to a patient can make for fuzzy views.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a small new study, the chemical that makes chocolate a mild stimulant outperformed codeine in suppressing coughs. Treating anything with chocolate always has its fans, but what is of greatest interest to the researchers is the way the chemical, theobromine, appears to work.

headline.main: And It Doesn't Taste Bad, Either

docs.abstract: Dr Peter J Barnes of Britain's National Heart and Lung Institute leads study that finds theobromine, chemical in dark chocolate, is effective cough suppressant; study is published in journal of Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology (S)
docs.snippet: In a small new study, the chemical that makes chocolate a mild stimulant outperformed codeine in suppressing coughs.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: FEDERATION OF AMERICAN SOCIETIES FOR EXPERIMENTAL BIOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: I remember all too well the agony of postsurgical starvation: nearly five days elapsed after my Caesarean section when the hospital refused to give me anything but ice chips. All the while I was trying to nurse two big babies with nothing but an intravenous glucose solution to sustain me. But the nurses held firm. I had not yet passed gas or had a bowel movement. Complaining bitterly, I asked, ''How can you expect my bowels to work if I'm not putting anything in them?''

headline.main: A Serving of Reality With Surgical Fasts

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses validity of requiring patients to fast before and after surgical procedures; holds that 1999 American Society of Anesthesiology guidelines, which relax long-held mandate that patients take nothing by mouth after midnight, are based on scientific data, not presumptions; guidelines outlined; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Longstanding limitations on food and drink before and after surgery have been found to be unnecessary and even detrimental.

docs.lead_paragraph: More time outside for baby in the afternoon goes along with more quiet time at night, according to a British study that will appear in the December issue of The Journal of Sleep Research. The study compared babies who slept well with problem sleepers and found that the good sleepers had been exposed to twice as much light between noon and 4 p.m.
docs.abstract: Dr Yvonne Harrison of Liverpool John Moores University leads research that shows infants exposed to twice as much afternoon sunlight than other babies have better sleep patterns; findings, published in Journal of Sleep Research, suggest light exposure may help establish circadian rhythms for infants; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: More time outside for baby in the afternoon goes along with more quiet time at night, according to a British study.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, he had a mild case of conjunctivitis. His left eye was a little bit bloodshot and kept tearing up, and the lid was a little swollen. It wasn't anything you would take to a doctor, and it certainly wasn't serious enough to slow down an active 13-year-old. So on Friday, he was playing basketball, when, in a literal double whammy, he got hit in the left eye with the ball.

headline.main: For a Teenage Boy, a Basketball and a Bug Spell Trouble

docs.abstract: Dr Perri Klass Cases article describes young man with typical eye infection that was worsened by impact of being hit with basketball; ailment developed into serious infection requiring hospital stay and intravenous antibiotics; various types of eye infections discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In one young patient, unidentified stalkers seek out openings to attack the vision.
